word.entryDescription: tall thick tropical grass with young shoots that pandas like to eat
word.entryExample: Pandas eat a lot of bamboo leaves.

word.entryDescription: a long tropical fruit with a thick yellow skin, and soft white flesh
word.entryExample: Monkeys love bananas.

word.entryDescription: a group of people who play music together
word.entryExample: That band I saw was the most popular and I was really lucky to get tickets.

word.entryDescription: a long cloth which you wrap around an injury
word.entryExample: The doctor told me that I had to wear a bandage.

word.entryDescription: a sudden loud noise
word.entryExample: Suddenly, there was huge bang and a flash of light.

word.entryDescription: a business that looks after people's money
word.entryExample: Is there a bank near here?

word.entryDescription: a rectangular piece of plastic issued by a bank for credit or information purposes
word.entryExample: This account usually comes with a bank card.

word.entryDescription: forbidden by law or some other regulations
word.entryExample: Do you think there are some foods that should be banned from schools?

word.entryDescription: a meal cooked outside, usually on a metal frame over a fire
word.entryExample: We're going to have a barbecue in the back garden.

word.entryDescription: something on offer for less than its usual price; something that is appealing because it seems cheap
word.entryExample: I love buying clothes in the sales – you can find some real bargains, even things at half price!

word.entryDescription: a large round container with a flat top and bottom, usually used for storing liquids such as beer, wine, etc
word.entryExample: In the past, wooden barrels were used to store liquids.

word.entryDescription: a team sport in which people hit a ball with a long thin bat and then run around four bases
word.entryExample: Baseball is an American game.

word.entryDescription: a small round hat that fits closely on your head with a round part at the front to keep the sun from your face
word.entryExample: Wear your baseball cap outside in the sun.

word.entryDescription: the floor of a building below ground level
word.entryExample: We keep our bikes in the basement.

word.entryDescription: an open container in the bathroom or toilet where you can wash
word.entryExample: Under the basin or near the toilet there may be cleaning products, which are often poisonous.

word.entryDescription: a geographical feature, a bit like a bowl
word.entryExample: In LA people commute across a basin that is fifty miles wide.

word.entryDescription: a team sport played on a court in which people bounce a ball and throw it into a round open net
word.entryExample: Ben is tall and he's good at basketball.
It'll be really hot, so we're taking our bathing suits, shorts, t-shirts and sunglasses.

word.entryDescription: a room where you shower and wash or go to the toilet
word.entryExample: Excuse me, where is bathroom?

word.entryDescription: the player whose job is to hit the ball in cricket
word.entryExample: The batsman has to hit the ball, so that it does not hit the wicket.

word.entryDescription: a small object which you put inside an electrical device to give it power
word.entryExample: William thinks Kate's phone must have run out of battery.

word.entryDescription: a place where lots of animals are kept in very crowded conditions
word.entryExample: Keeping a few chickens means you don't have to buy eggs from battery farms.

word.entryDescription: the abbreviation for 'barbecue'
word.entryExample: I’m having a BBQ in the garden this weekend.

word.entryDescription: to have the knowledge, skill or possibility to do something
word.entryExample: Miriam was able to buy some new tickets.

word.entryDescription: to be made less or smaller (in size, amount, price, etc)
word.entryExample: The tiger's natural habitat has been reduced by human activity.

word.entryDescription: an area of sand at the edge of the sea
word.entryExample: Kim and Jill are at the beach.

word.entryDescription: a large strong animal with thick fur and long sharp claws
word.entryExample: Are there any bears in the forest?

word.entryDescription: hair that a man grows on his face.
word.entryExample: My dad is growing a beard.

word.entryDescription: having a beard (= the hair that grows on man's chin and cheeks)
word.entryExample: That bearded tall man looks exactly like my cousin.

word.entryDescription: to defeat a person or team in a game, race, etc
word.entryExample: You tried to beat me and you played a good game.

word.entryDescription: very nice to look at
word.entryExample: What a beautiful dress!

word.entryDescription: an animal with thick fur and a wide flat tail, able to cut down trees with its strong teeth
word.entryExample: Beavers are known for buliding dams across rivers.

word.entryDescription: a piece of furniture that you sleep on
word.entryExample: I can't sleep on my old bed – I need a new one.

word.entryDescription: a room for sleeping in
word.entryExample: This is my lovely bedroom.

word.entryDescription: earlier than
word.entryExample: I take my dog for a walk before it gets dark.

word.entryDescription: past simple of 'begin' – to start
word.entryExample: When the last part of the relay race began, Ms Green's class were in last place.

word.entryDescription: expression used to introduce the first point you want to make
word.entryExample: 'What didn't you like about the film?' 'Well, to begin with, the special effects were not very good…'

word.entryDescription: somebody who has just started learning something
word.entryExample: Whether you are a beginner or a seasoned outdoor climber, we can offer you a challenging and enjoyable day out.

word.entryDescription: to do things in a particular way
word.entryExample: Some teachers said she behaved very badly.

word.entryDescription: at the back of
word.entryExample: Sam is sitting behind Ben.

word.entryDescription: to think that something is true or that someone is telling the truth
word.entryExample: His teacher told Mo to run more, because he believed he could be a great runner.

word.entryDescription: a long narrow accessory worn around the waist
word.entryExample: A belt stops your trousers from falling down.

word.entryDescription: a long wooden seat
word.entryExample: We sat on a bench in the park.

word.entryDescription: producing a good effect or advantage
word.entryExample: Being able to speak the local language when you live in a foreign country is hugely beneficial.

word.entryDescription: a small, round, juicy fruit
word.entryExample: Let's go to the forest and pick some berries!

word.entryDescription: next to
word.entryExample: The Dive School is beside the hotel.

word.entryDescription: used to talk about the person or thing that is the most satisfactory or the highest quality; the comparative of 'good'
word.entryExample: Alex is the best at reading and writing.

word.entryDescription: the most important friend you have
word.entryExample: Who is your best friend?

word.entryDescription: more satisfactory or higher in quality than other similar people or things; the superlative of 'good'
word.entryExample: I'm better at running than swimming.

word.entryDescription: in the space which separates two things
word.entryExample: The hospital is between the bus station and the park.
